newsitem.title: USA: Boston convention center closer to reality.
newsitem.headline: Boston convention center closer to reality.

text.p: The bid to build a new convention center in Boston moved a step closer to reality Wednesday after economic development projects important to other parts of the state were attached to it.

The State Administration Committee approved Gov. William Weld's May proposal calling for construction of a $700 million convention center and exhibition hall on Summer Street in South Boston. But as State House News Service reported melded into that measure is the $62 million Weld had requested in a capital outlay bill to bolster similar projects in Springfield, Worcester, Lenox and Fall River.

And the bill swelled even more after the Senate committee chairman on Tuesday won an amendment to assure that an added $30 million would be available for economic development and tourism in the "Greater Southeastern part of Massachusetts."

In addition to the convention center deemed key to the economy of both the city and the region, the bill also calls for capital expenditures of $25 million for the planned overhaul and expansion of the National Basketball of Fame in Springfield, $14 million to rehabilitate the Springfield Civic Center; $17 million to expand convention space in Worcester; $2.5 million for a planned national music center in Lenox; and $3.5 million for a industrial park development in Fall River.
The measure moves now to the House Long-Term Debt and Capital Expenditure Committee, which plans to act on it later on Wednesday.

It will then wend its way to the House Ways and Means Committee before debate begins in the full House. Speaker Thomas Finneran has predicted it will win House passage before a planned summer recess later this month.

Questions over how the Boston project will be financed have stalled it in recent years, but top city and state officials appear to have reached a tentative agreement on how much each of them, and the businesses that will benefit from the complex, will pay to support it.
